title: Rowena Crest Viewpoint
listingDescription: Obtained as a gift from Mark Mayer in 1924, the Rowena Crest Viewpoint is a paved overlook located near the top of the high bluffs on the south side of the Columbia River. It offers magnificent views of the Columbia River Gorge, interpretive exhibits, and hiking trails through a nature preserve. When the spring wildflowers are in bloom, this is one of the most stunning vistas in the Gorge.

images.altText: An wide river stretches through a heavily forested gorge under a cloudy sky.
images.title: Rowena Crest Viewpoint
images.caption: Take in the view at the Rowena Crest Overlook in the Columbia River Gorge in Oregon.

bodyText:
Obtained as a gift from Mark Mayer in 1924, the Rowena Crest Viewpoint is a paved overlook located near the top of the high bluffs on the south side of the Columbia River. It offers magnificent views of the Columbia River Gorge, interpretive exhibits, and hiking trails through a nature preserve. When the spring wildflowers are in bloom, this is one of the most stunning vistas in the Gorge.

Site Information

Location (Mayer State Park, Mosier, Oregon)

The viewpoint is part of nearby 640 acre Mayer State Park and is reached by driving Highway 30 (a paved, windy road), located south of the park entrance. Other park amenities include swimming, boating, fishing and picnicking. 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
The entrance drive makes a loop on the top of this steep bluff, enclosed by a stone wall on the right and a wood-and-wire fence on the left. The river lies below, stretching out in the gorge that extends in both directions. A town nestles along the banks at the base of the bluff on the far side. Looking over the wall to the right, we see the narrow road making hairpin turns as it winds up the side of the bluff through mixed woodlands. Looking straight down from the end, we see the interstate highway passing far below.

The middle of the looping drive has gravel walks through low plantings of grasses. A metal sign on a large gray boulder tells us the "Rowena Crest Native Planting was dedicated June 1991 in memory of Robert G.H. Ellis, Jr, conservationist. This area has been restored with plants native to the locale." A bench sits in the middle.

There are two wayside signs along the stone wall. The one on the right talks about the looping road below. It reads in part, "Gazing down upon the graceful, winding Historic Columbia River Highway, it is easy to forget how challenging its construction was in the early 20th century. One of the first modern paved thoroughfares in the Pacific Northwest, it traversed a rugged landscape from water level to breathtaking heights above the river. Despite the extreme terrain, engineer John A. Elliott determined that the Highway's eastern section should be built in concert with the gentle turns and grade of its western end as designed by Samuel C. Lancaster. Here, echoing the loops at Crown Point and Hood River, the road climbs a rise, encircles this overlook, and then loops downward in graceful, sweeping S-turns along the cliff face."

The other sign reads "Volcanism, uplift, erosion and human endeavor have indelibly etched the Columbia River Gorge. But cataclysmic floods during the last Ice Age (12,000 to 15,000 years ago) affected the landscape before you more than any other terrestrial force, creating these scablands called the Rowen Plateau. As a massive ice sheet advanced from Canada, it dammed rivers with up to 2,000 feet of glacial ice creating huge lakes across Idaho and Montana. The largest of these, 3,000 square mile glacial Lake Missoula, held over 500 cubic miles of water - half the volume of Lake Michigan. When rising waters undermined these ice dams, tremendous floods swept across the land and down the Columbia River. Torrents of water and ice raged downstream as many as 100 times, scouring away soils at elevations up to 1,000 feet."

title: Santa Fe Park
listingDescription: Santa Fe Park preserves approximately one-quarter mile of Oregon, California, and Santa Fe trail ruts in the heart of the city of Independence, Missouri. These ruts align with trail ruts found a half mile north on the Bingham-Waggoner estate, a 19.5 acre museum and park, that is open to the public.

images.altText: Trees surround a large grass meadow, which contains a shallow, long, u-shaped depression made by Oregon Trail traffic
images.caption: Santa Fe Park Oregon Trail Swales

bodyText:
Santa Fe Park preserves approximately one-quarter mile of Oregon, California, and Santa Fe trail ruts in the heart of the city of Independence, Missouri. These ruts align with trail ruts found a half mile north on the Bingham-Waggoner estate, a 19.5 acre museum and park, that is open to the public. The roads in between the two locations reveal the importance of the historic trails did not end when emigrant trail traffic ended. Often, as was the case throughout what is now the Kansas City metropolitan area, sections of the trail were converted into roads as automobiles replaced covered wagons, continuing the trails importance to this very day.

Site Information

Location (2900 South Santa Fe Road, Independence, Missouri)

Amenities at the 45 acre Santa Fe Park including walking trails, a picnic pavilion, a dog park, and tennis courts. 

 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

Santa Fe National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
Santa Fe Park. 108 words

Along the side of the parking lot in this park is a cement marker post standing on a closely mowed grassy expanse. Small signs on the front identify the Santa Fe Trail and the Oregon and California Trails. Between 85 and 100 yards to the right of the marker, near a street light, are gentle swales running perpendicular to the roadway. A swale is shallow trough or ditch, which is a remnant of the tracks left by the wagons as they headed west. Although clearly visible to the eye, the swales may be too shallow to discern by walking across them.

title: Schumacher Park
listingDescription: Travelers on the Oregon, California, and Santa Fe trails passed through what is now Schumacher Park as they journeyed through the prairie of the great plains. They passed through the south end of the park in an east to west direction during the mid-1800s. Today, no traces of these trails (no ruts or swales) remain in the park, but the park does provide a good example of how this part of Kansas appeared in the 19th century.

images.altText: A moderately developed park with benches, a monument and a gazebo set in a landscape of prairie and forest
images.caption: Schumacher Park Site Overview

bodyText:
Travelers on the Oregon, California, and Santa Fe trails passed through what is now Schumacher Park as they journeyed through the prairie of the great plains. They passed through the south end of the park in an east to west direction during the mid-1800s. Today, no traces of these trails (no ruts or swales) remain in the park, but the park does provide a good example of how this part of Kansas appeared to 19th century emigrants. The park's natural ecosystem, the prairie, has been restored by reseeding the area with a diversity of native grasses and wildflowers. . 

Site Information

Location (6601 East 93rd Street, Kansas City, Missouri)

A short part of the trail route has been marked and offers an opportunity to walk through this prairie. Interpretive exhibits throughout the park tell the story of the trails. Other park features include a sheltered picnic area, wayside markers, and panoramic views 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

Santa Fe National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
Schumacher Park. 386 words

From the parking area along the side of the street you face a large, pink granite marker enclosed by a black metal fence. The marker reads, "Santa Fe Trail, 1821 - 1872, Marker by the Daughters of the American Revolution and the State of Missouri, 1909."

Slightly to the right of that, a large stone sign, place perpendicular to the street reads, "Santa Fe National Historic Trail, Schumacher Park." Below that are the three logos for the trails, each shaped like a rounded, equilateral triangle. The one for the Santa Fe Trail shows a covered wagon pulled by a team of 6 oxen. The one for the Oregon Trail shows just a covered wagon. The one for the California Trail shows a yoke for oxen with the curved top bar and two "U"-shaped extensions below.

To the left of the fenced area a broad, cement sidewalk leads into the park, then curves behind the fencing. Behind the marker, another walkway leads back to a large covered pavilion, about 20 feet wide and 35 feet deep. The front half of this area has picnic tables, two on either side. Along the sides at the rear of the pavilion are 4 waysides signs. One titled "The Capitalists" discusses trade and merchantmen. The next is titled "Los Capitalistas" and discusses the traders and merchants at the New Mexico end of the Santa Fe Trail. Another is titled "Bias and Business" and covers the role of women, American Indians and slaves in trade. The last panel is titled "Cultures in Collision" and discusses the impact of the many trail travelers on native populations.

The rear of the park property is covered with native prairie plantings -- tall and medium grasses and a variety of wildflowers.

On either side of the sidewalk behind the stone marker are two more waysides, one discussing the three trails that passed through this region and the other discussing the role of the Daughters of the American Revolution or DAR in locating and marking the original route of the Santa Fe Trail.

From the fenced area, the sidewalk leads another 50 yards to the right to one final wayside sign which discusses the disappearance of trail remnants due to modern development and the use of maps and aerial photographs to identify the routes.

title: Scotts Bluff National Monument
listingDescription: Scotts Bluff National Monument is named for an immense section of sandstone and clay bluffs that tower 800 feet above the North Platte River. This 3000 acre monument is managed by the National Park Service and has numerous amenities and things to do.

images.altText: Two covered wagons sit in a grassy field in front of a large rock outcropping.
images.title: Scotts Bluff National Monument
images.caption: Visit Scott's Bluff National Monument.

bodyText:
Scotts Bluff National Monument is named for an immense section of sandstone and clay bluffs that tower 800 feet above the North Platte River. This 3000 acre monument is managed by the National Park Service and has numerous amenities and things to do. A visitor center contains exhibits about the geological, paleontological, and human history of the monument, including exhibits about the Oregon Trail and its travelers. The visitor center also contains a bookstore and plays an introductory film. Addition features of the monument include a paved road that allows visitors to drive to the top of the bluffs, numerous interpretive waysides, several hiking trails, and magnificent views. Restrooms drinking water, soda machines, and picnic tables are available. Plan to stay for a minimum of two hours to enjoy the park. Modest admission is charged.

Site Information

Location (Three miles west of Gering, Nebraska on Old Oregon Trail (Highway 92 West))

Scotts Bluff National Monument

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

Pony Express National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
Scotts Bluff National Monument. 217 words

The visitor center here consists of a long, rectangular building made of tan adobe, extending parallel to the parking lot. At the left end, a two-story wing extends back away from the parking lot. Where the two wings meet, the wide sidewalk leads through an archway to the entrance. Dark brown wooden shingles cover the roof. Restrooms are at the far right end of the building.

The massive bluff itself, with its tan and brown layers, rises behind and to the left of the building. Immediately to the left is the flat cliff face of the south end, looking like someone sliced it with a knife.

The main structure has no windows but there is decorative open grillwork just under the eaves. A curved adobe wall lines the sidewalk from the parking lot. In front to the left of the entrance is a flagpole with a granite-topped, brick vault next to it. Engraved text on the granite reads, "Time Capsule, sealed December 12, 1994, to be opened December 12, 2069."

As you enter the building, the information desk extends parallel to the left-hand wall. On the right side of the door is a small seating area, with the entrance to the exhibit area just beyond. The gift shop is straight ahead.
passportStampLocationDescription: For more information about Passport Stamps, inquire at the site.

title: Scotts Bluff National Monument, the Oregon Trail
listingDescription: The bluffs of Scotts Bluff National Monument rise directly from the North Platte River, blocking wagon travel along the river's south bank. At first, emigrants had to take a detour south and use Robidoux Pass, a natural gateway, to get through the bluffs. This mostly stopped in 1850 when a new route was opened at Mitchell Pass.

images.altText: Six painted ox sculptures hooked to a replica of a historic wagon against a back drop of grass, blue skies, and a towering, grey natural rock formation
images.caption: Oregon Trail Pathway at Scotts Bluff National Monument

bodyText:
The bluffs of Scotts Bluff National Monument rise directly from the North Platte River, blocking wagon travel along the river's south bank. At first, emigrants had to take a detour south and use Robidoux Pass, a natural gateway, to get through the bluffs. This mostly stopped in 1850 when a new route was opened at Mitchell Pass. Located close to the North Platte River, this route saved emigrants nearly 15 miles of travel. The route, though, was narrow, due to the land's geography. As such, more than 300,000 emigrants, and their wagons and livestock, had to travel on the same strip of land. Eventually, deep ruts formed as a result of this traffic. These ruts are still visible today and are now a part of Scotts Bluff National Monument. A section of them has been developed into a walking trail with interpretive waysides.

Emigrant Remarks

In 1845, General Philip St. George Cooke marveled at the strange formation that rose before him.

"Looming afar over river and plain was 'Scott's Bluff,' a Nebraska Gibralter; surmounted by a colossal fortress and a royal castle, it jutted on the water. . . . This morning marched three miles still nearer to that mysterious mountain . . . without being disenchanted of its colossal ruins and phantom occupants."

Site Information

Location (Three miles west of Gering, Nebraska on Old Oregon Trail (Highway 92 West))

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

Pony Express National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
To reach the walking trail, cross the access road at the left of the visitor center. The sidewalk on the other side leads back to the left towards the highway and then turns right to parallel the highway. Once past the curve, there are four reproductions of different style emigrant vehicles along the right side of the sidewalk as well as several wayside signs. Please feel free to touch any of the vehicles. To the left, on the other side of the road are more bluffs, layered in tan and brown. A cylindrical feature sits on top of the bluff nearest to the road.

The first emigrant vehicle along the sidewalk, located about where the surface changes from smooth cement to a rougher aggregate, is a handcart. It has a small, square structure sitting directly over the two large wagon wheels with simple poles and a crosspiece extending in front for pulling it.

A wayside sign near the handcart asks which route would you take? Before 1851, many emigrants took a long detour to the south through Robidoux Pass. Later a one-wagon wide trail was created through the ravines of these bluffs here at Mitchell Pass.

Next is a common wagon, green in color with off-white canvas stretched on the overhead hoops. The rear wheels are larger than those in the front. The next wagon is very similar, this one painted white.

The final wagon is larger, painted pale blue. The wagon bottom is slightly curved to the middle and the front and rear ends are angled outward. This one has a team of model oxen in front, wearing wooden yokes with chains running back to the tongue of the wagon.

Past the last wagon, the sidewalk changes to a dirt and gravel path. A wayside sign here tells us that traffic went both ways through the pass. Fur traders traveled both directions, but some of the emigrants gave up and turned back eastward. Others returned to bring other family members out west. Traders drove massive freight wagons in both directions and Army units rode both ways as they patrolled the route.

The trail continues around the base of Scotts Bluff, the flat end rising high above you on the right. Meadow vegetation lines the path along with earthen and rocky outcroppings. The path may be rough and uneven in places. More waysides at the end of the trail talk about how emigrants might get assistance along the trail and one shows a painting by William Henry Jackson that depicts the view of the trail looking back eastward through the pass, matching the current location of the sign.

title: Shawnee Indian Mission State Historic Site, Fairway
listingDescription: The Shawnee Mission was one of many missions established as a manual training school attended by boys and girls from Shawnee, Delaware, and other Indian nations from 1839 to 1862.

images.altText: The pillar and plague for Shawnee Indian Missions and one of the red brick buildings
images.title: Shawnee Indian Mission in Fairway Kansas
images.caption: Shawnee Indian Mission in Fairway Kansas

bodyText:
The Shawnee Mission was one of many missions established as a manual training school attended by boys and girls from Shawnee, Delaware, and other Indian nations from 1839 to 1862. It was also a popular overland trail campground for emigrants.

Site Information

Location (3403 W. 53rd Street (between Mission Road and Reinhardt Street), Fairway Kansas)

Available Facilities
Three buildings dating from the historic period (the east, north, and west buildings) are still standing, two of which are open to public visitation.

Exhibits
The North Building and the two-story East Building are laden with exhibits that describe six historic themes, one of which is the overland trails.

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Exhibit Audio Description available

Santa Fe National Historic Trail

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
Shawnee Indian Mission State Historic Site. 411 words

This site has three historic, red-brick buildings and several smaller structures on both sides of the street. A stone sign near the entrance to the parking lot reads "Shawnee Indian Mission" and directly across the street is a stone marker proclaiming this as a state historic site. Another marker identifies this as a Registered National Historic Landmark. The buildings sit on grassy lawns with scattered trees. Some of the tree are black walnuts with their large round fruits on the ground underneath.

One building is right next to the parking lot. A sign on the far side tells us that this is the East Building, erected in 1840-41, which "provided a chapel and classrooms, and living quarters for the teachers. Indian boys slept in the attic. The first territorial legislature met here in 1855 and enacted the so-called Bogus Laws in an attempt to perpetuate slavery in Kansas." To the left of the building at the far end of the parking lot is a plot of land enclosed by split-rail fencing with several historic wooden buildings. Also at that end of the building, out in the middle of the lawn sits a covered wagon. Feel free to touch this exhibit.

A sidewalk leads from the end of the East Building nearest the street which crosses a stream via a small wooden bridge and leads to the West Building. This building also has two stories and has a wing extending towards the rear. The wing has a second story porch enclosed by white railings and reached by an outside stairway next to the main building. A sign in front of this building tells us that "This is the oldest of the three mission buildings now standing. Built in 1839 it was used for classrooms and living quarters for superintendents and teachers. Territorial officials had offices and rooms here in 1854-1856."

At the front left corner of this building is a garden of native plants. Behind it is a small vegetable garden enclosed by a 4-foot-high wooden fence.

The other building sits on the other side of the street. Also two stories, it has a two-story porch along the front with outside stairways leading up from either end. A sign tells us that "This building, erected in 1845, was the dormitory and school for Indian girls. Here they were taught spinning, weaving, and other domestic arts. Andrew H. Reeder, first territorial governor of Kansas, had executive offices here."

title: South Pass
listingDescription: South Pass , a 20 mile wide, gently sloping gap in the Rocky Mountains, was perhaps the most important landform along the emigrant trails. It opened the West to settlement by providing a route over the Continental Divide that wagons could negotiate. Everyone who followed the Oregon Trail through Wyoming used this sagebrush and grass covered saddle. A wide and deep path was created as thousands of wagon wheels and livestock hooves steadily eroded the ground.

images.altText: An endless plain covered in sagebrush and dried grass with two, inscribed, vertical stone markers in the foreground
images.caption: South Pass Site Overview

bodyText:
South Pass, a 20 mile wide, gently sloping gap in the Rocky Mountains, was perhaps the most important landform along the emigrant trails. It opened the West to settlement by providing a route over the Continental Divide that wagons could negotiate. Everyone who followed the Oregon Trail through Wyoming used this sagebrush and grass covered saddle. A wide and deep path was created as thousands of wagon wheels and livestock hooves steadily eroded the ground. The Oregon, California, Mormon Pioneer, and Pony Express National Historic Trails passed through here.

Emigrant Remarks

On July 12, 1846, Edwin Bryant made his way

"up a very gentle ascent to the south pass of the Rocky Mountains, or the dividing ridge separating the waters of the Atlantic and the Pacific. The ascent to the Pass is so gradual, that but for our geographical knowledge . . . we should not have been conscious that we had ascended to, and were standing upon the summit of the Rocky Mountains-the backbone . . . of the North American Continent."

Site Information

Location (From South Pass Rest Area, go south on Wyoming Highway 28 for 0.9 miles to reach Oregon Buttes Road (Fremont County 445). Turn left (southeast) onto this well-maintained dirt road. Drive 2.8 miles, slowing where the road begins curving to the right. Turn right (west) onto the two-track road that begins near the curve and drive 0.8 miles.)

South Pass National Historic Landmark, which is managed by the Bureau of Land Management, preserves these still visible ruts. The landmark is free and open to the public. Amenities are scarce; only a few monuments and signs mark the South Pass crossing. Roads in the landmark are all unpaved, but the main ones are maintained, gravel roads suitable for most vehicles when dry.

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail

Pony Express National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
South Pass. 401 words

There is a wayside sign here at the intersection of a rough dirt track and the main gravel road. The land stretches away in all directions, sagebrush-covered prairie as far as the eye can see. Cement posts, one to the east along the dirt road and one to the west, mark the path of the Oregon Trail. To the north a distant mountain range can be seen. To the west is the slanted end of a butte, which extends away to the south. Another butte is visible in the distant south.

The sign at the intersection reads, "To the south stand the Oregon Buttes, a major trail landmark. The name is significant because the buttes were roughly the beginning of the Oregon Territory and also helped keep emigrants encouraged, even though there were still hundreds of miles of rough going ahead. Today the Oregon Buttes are an Area of Critical Environmental Concern because of their cultural significance and important wildlife values.

"About twelve miles to the southwest of Oregon Buttes is the Tri-Territory site. This site is the location where the Oregon Territory, Mexican Territory and Louisiana Purchase had a common border. The large landmark, just to the south of where you are standing, is Pacific Butte. The great height and mass of the butte, combined with a ridge to the north paralleling the emigrant trails, helps to create a visual channel through which travelers migrated on their way through South Pass."

Following the dirt road to the west leads to another wayside sign and a fenced area with two stone markers. Parallel wagon swales are barely discernable through the sagebrush on both sides of the road. The sign tells us the South Pass was first discovered in 1812. Bonneville took the first wagons over the pass in 1832 and Fremont widely publicized the route after his expedition in 1842. Thousands of Mormons, future Oregonians and Californians would use the trail in the following twenty years.

The two stone markers are on the north side of the dirt road. The larger one is a five-foot tall rock slab, reddish-tan in color, roughly rectangular with carved lettering that reads, "Old Oregon Trail, 1843-57." The other stone slab marker is about 3 feet tall and is charcoal gray. It reads, "Narcissa Prentiss Whitman, Eliza Hart Spalding, First white women to cross this pass, July 4, 1836."

Drive 2.8 miles, slowing where the road begins curving to the right. Turn right (west) onto the two-track road that begins near the curve and drive 0.8 miles.

title: South Pass Overlook
listingDescription: South Pass Overlook is a Bureau of Land Management interpretive site with views of several trail landmarks including Pacific Springs, South Pass and the Oregon Buttes. A short, paved pathway contains several interpretive waysides that tell the story of South Pass's importance to American Indians, mountain men, the fur trade, and to the Oregon, Mormon, California, and Pony Express trails.

images.altText: A paved path with two wayside signs is in front of a sagebrush and dried grass plain that stretches between two ridgelines
images.caption: South Pass from South Pass Overlook

bodyText:
South Pass Overlook is a Bureau of Land Management interpretive site with views of several trail landmarks including Pacific Springs, South Pass and the Oregon Buttes. A short, paved pathway contains several interpretive waysides that tell the story of South Pass's importance to American Indians, mountain men, the fur trade, and to the Oregon, Mormon, California, and Pony Express trails.

Site Information

Location (5.3 miles southwest of South Pass Rest Area on the east side of WY-28)

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail

Pony Express National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
South Pass Overlook. 233 words

On the south side of the dirt parking area is a paved loop overlooking the wide pass below. Wayside signs are spaced along the walkway. To the southeast lies the long flat ridgetop of Pacific Butte, as identified by a map on one of the signs. Directly south are the more distant peaks of Oregon Buttes. Turning back to the northeast, the southern end of the Wind River mountain range is visible in the distance. In all directions, as far as the eye can see, the land is covered with short sagebrush, prairie vegetation.

The wayside signs cover such topics as the path of the trails west of this point, the role of South Pass as a corridor westward, and the fur trade.

One sign has a drawing of the landscape, labeling the prominent features. It reads, "South Pass, on top of the world. From where you're standing South Pass doesn't look all that remarkable. But compared to the rugged Wind River Mountains, it can easily be recognized as a type of gateway. Nevertheless, crossing the Continental Divide into 'Oregon Country' was a task for all westward-bound travelers and many described their feelings about the event. In 1852 Lucy Rutledge Cooke, a young woman with 'California Fever' wrote, 'This morn we arrived at the South Pass after which all rivers we see will be running to the Pacific.'"

title: South Pass- Oregon Buttes
listingDescription: The Oregon Buttes consist of two flat-top hills and a smaller conical shaped hill. This landform, which is visible from South Pass, roughly marked the emigrants' entry into the Oregon Territory.

images.altText: A long, narrow grass, sagebrush, and scattered tree covered ridgeline extends into a vast sagebrush and dried grass plain
images.caption: View from the Top of Oregon Buttes

bodyText:
The Oregon Buttes consist of two flat-top hills and a smaller conical shaped hill. This landform, which is visible from South Pass, roughly marked the emigrants' entry into the Oregon Territory. Rising to an elevation of 8612 feet out of the northwestern portion of the Red Desert, they also made for a prominent landmark. To Oregon Trail travelers coming from the east, the buttes dominated the horizon for a day's travel or more as they crossed Rock Creek, then Willow Creek and, for a ninth and final time, the Sweetwater River.

Site Information

Location (the Oregon Buttes can be viewed from South Pass and Oregon Buttes Road. To explore the buttes, contact the Lander Field Office of the Bureau of Land Management)

Today, the buttes are covered with a wide variety of vegetation types including limber pine stands, thick aspen stands, and wet meadows. They are also located in a remote area that can be difficult to access and has few, if any, amenities and services. 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
There is a wayside sign here at the intersection of a rough dirt track and the main gravel road. The land stretches away in all directions, sagebrush-covered prairie as far as the eye can see. Cement posts, one to the east along the dirt road and one to the west, mark the path of the Oregon Trail. To the north a distant mountain range can be seen. To the west is the slanted end of a butte, which extends away to the south. Another butte is visible in the distant south.

The name is significant because the buttes were roughly the beginning of the Oregon Territory and also helped keep emigrants encouraged, even though there were still hundreds of miles of rough going ahead. Today the Oregon Buttes are an Area of Critical Environmental Concern because of their cultural significance and important wildlife values.

"About twelve miles to the southwest of Oregon Buttes is the Tri-Territory site. This site is the location where the Oregon Territory, Mexican Territory and Louisiana Purchase had a common border. The large landmark, just to the south of where you are standing, is Pacific Butte. The great height and mass of the butte, combined with a ridge to the north paralleling the emigrant trails, helps to create a visual channel through which travelers migrated on their way through South Pass."

Bonneville took the first wagons over the pass in 1832 and Fremont widely publicized the route after his expedition in 1842. Thousands of Mormons, future Oregonians and Californians would use the trail in the following twenty years.

The two stone markers are on the north side of the dirt road. The larger one is a five-foot tall rock slab, reddish-tan in color, roughly rectangular with carved lettering that reads, "Old Oregon Trail, 1843-57." The other stone slab marker is about 3 feet tall and is charcoal gray. It reads, "Narcissa Prentiss Whitman, Eliza Hart Spalding, First white women to cross this pass, July 4, 1836."

title: Split Rock
listingDescription: Split Rock is a "gun sight" notched landform that rises 1000 feet above the sagebrush plains. It was visible to emigrants for two days or more as they approached, and then, left it behind. Some of the emigrants found the landform to be a useful navigational tool, since it guided them directly to South Pass. The Bureau of Land Management has developed an interpretive site on the south side of Split Rock.

images.altText: Behind a sagebrush and dried grass plain, rises a highly fractured, barren, tan and grey natural rock formation
images.caption: Distant Waysides at Split Rock Site

bodyText:
Split Rock is a "gun sight" notched landform that rises 1000 feet above the sagebrush plains. It was visible to emigrants for two days or more as they approached, and then, left it behind. Some of the emigrants found the landform to be a useful navigational tool, since it guided them directly to South Pass. The Bureau of Land Management has developed an interpretive site on the south side of Split Rock. A short hiking trail, with interpretive panels regarding the area and its history, leads to an overlook of Split Rock. A second highway turn-out a few miles west offers a good (although reversed) view of the "split" in the rock. 

Emigrant Remarks

"[Y]esterday," Joseph Middleton wrote in 1849, "from the time we started we steered to this cliff with a steadiness that was astonishing, never deviating from it more than the needle does from the north pole, excepting once for a short time-I think this cleft or rent or chasm is very conspicuously seen from the Devil's Gate, which I think is 11 miles from here; and I think it is still at least 6 or 8 miles ahead. ..."

Site Information

Location (east of Jeffrey City, Wyoming)

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail

Pony Express National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
Split Rock. 232 words

From the parking lot a paved trail leads out on the flat ridge top to a spot overlooking the flat meadows below. The low vegetation consists primarily of grasses and sagebrush. On the other side of the narrow valley are granite ridges and outcroppings. Several wayside signs are located along the path.

One tells us that Split Rock was a well-known trail landmark and navigation aid. Emigrants were guided by the rock for an entire day's travel from the east and it remained in view behind them for another two days. Travel time from here to South Pass was about 6 days. The granite rocks seen in front of you are the side view of Split Rock. Photographs on the sign show the view of the notch from the trail, which passes east of this location. One picture shows a pair of ruts running away from you into the distance. At the upper right is a flat-topped granite hill. On the left side of the flat ridge, is a notch, almost a perfect "V" shape.

Other signs discuss the Pony Express, wild horses in the west, and the westward trails. Along the trail near the parking lot is a small stone marker with a panel indicating that Split Rock in on the National Register of Historic Places.

Restrooms are located at the other end of the parking lot.

title: St. Mary's Mission and Oregon Trail Nature Park
listingDescription: The St Mary’s Indian Pay Station was established at the St Mary’s Mission and school. The Pay Station building was where tribe members received their annual government payments based on previous treaties. The mission also served as a school to educate and “civilize” American Indian children. Today you can visit the site and the St Mary’s Indian Pay Station and Museum.

images.altText: The stone wall and metal fence around the entrance to St. Mary's Mission Museum.
images.title: St. Mary's Mission Museum
images.caption: St. Mary's Mission and Oregon Trail Nature Park, St. Marys, Kansas

bodyText:
The St Mary’s Indian Pay Station was established at the St Mary’s Mission and school. The Pay Station building was where tribe members received their annual government payments based on previous treaties. The mission also served as a school to educate and “civilize” American Indian children. Today you can visit the site and the St Mary’s Indian Pay Station and Museum.
Down the road from St Mary’s is the Oregon Trail Nature Park.  The historic Oregon Trail route passes through and features a mural painted on an old silo.  

 

Near St. Mary’s, the Oregon Trail passes through the Oregon Trail Nature Park. Located on the north edge of the Kaw River Valley, you follow the historic route to access the park. There are trail murals in the park to help you imagine the scene.  

Site Information

Location (111 E Mission St, St Marys, KS 66536) 


Safety Considerations
 

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

title: Strang Park, Overland Park
listingDescription: The Santa Fe Trail forked into two routes as it headed south from Westport. Along the routes were campgrounds for trail travelers — to the northeast of the junction was Sapling Grove and to the southwest was a campground called Flat Rock or Indian Creek. Until the 1860s, these two routes out of Westport saw traffic from Santa Fe traders, Oregon- and California-bound emigrants, mountain men, missionaries, gold seekers, and the frontier military.

images.altText: Wayside exhibits in front of a grassy field.
images.title: Strang Park Exhibits
images.caption: Visit Strange Park in Overland Park, Kansas.

bodyText:
The Santa Fe Trail forked into two routes as it headed south from Westport. Along the routes were campgrounds for trail travelers — to the northeast of the junction was Sapling Grove and to the southwest was a campground called Flat Rock or Indian Creek.

Until the 1860s, these two routes out of Westport saw traffic from Santa Fe traders, Oregon- and California-bound emigrants, mountain men, missionaries, gold seekers, and the frontier military. Even the frontier stagecoach of the early 1860s rumbled through this trail junction heading southwest.

Site Information 

Location (Overland Park, Kansas)

title: Studebaker Wagon Replica
listingDescription: The Studebaker Wagon was a common family wagon for hauling goods west.

images.altText: A Studebaker wagon is painted blue with red wheels and a canvas cover.
images.title: Studebaker Wagon
images.caption: Studebaker wagons were a common family wagon.

bodyText:
Please note that the Studebaker wagon may be placed in storage to protect it from the elements during the winter season. 

The Studebaker brothers began their enterprise in South Bend, Indiana. The Studebaker name was as recognizable as Murphy on the trail. As blacksmiths, they provided the hardware for many of the early wagon manufacturers. Nearly every wagon making the journey westward had their components and spare parts. They would later expand into manufacture ring wagons for emigrants and freighting companies.  

The influence of the family and their adaptive skills would extend into the modern era with the design and production of the Studebaker automobile.

The Studebaker wagon at Scotts Bluff was purchased by the Monument in 2009.
audioDescription: A Studebaker wagon replica sits off to the north side of the paved path.

title: Stuhr Museum of the Prairie Pioneer
listingDescription: Walk along original wagon swales, visit a Pawnee Indian earth lodge, and explore a “pioneer settlement” that interprets the 1850s-1860s road ranches—the truck stops of yore—that served emigration and freight traffic along the trail.

images.altText: A rectangular building sitting in the middle of a lake
images.title: Stuhr Museum of the Prairie Pioneer
images.caption: Visit the Visit the Stuhr Museum of the Prairie Pioneer in Grand Island, Nebraska

bodyText:
Walk along original wagon swales, visit a Pawnee Indian earth lodge, and explore a “pioneer settlement” that interprets the 1850s-1860s road ranches—the truck stops of yore—that served emigration and freight traffic along the trail. At this living history museum, you'll experience the life of those who travelled the trail years ago. 

The Stuhr Museum features an operational 1890s historic town featuring over 100 historic structures. The town has homes, businesses, and the thing that drives it all--a railroad! Additionally, historical interpreters are dressed in 1890s clothes and perform daily activities like baking, making horseshoes, and making hats. 

Visit the Stuhr Museum year-round, seven days a week. Open Monday-Saturday, 9 a.m.-5 p.m., Sunday, 12-5 p.m. Admission is charged.

Site Information

Location (3133 W US-34, Grand Island, Nebraska)

The Stuhr Museum is located in South Central Nebraska, approximately 94 miles West of Lincoln.  Amid the Midwest plains along the Platte River which guided many emigrants across North America, the museum is near the routes of the overland trails, including the California Trail, Oregon Trail, and Mormon Pioneer Trail.

The main museum building is world-renowned International Architecture Style building sitting in the center of a man-made lake. Numerous parking spaces line the edge of the lake. From the parking area, a wide foot bridge leads visitors across the water to the island where the main building sits. From the parking area, visitors can also walk through a lush, wooded area to ‘Railroad Town, NE’, a living history town featuring over 100 historic buildings and living historians dressed in period clothing.

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

California National Historic Trail

Oregon National Historic Trail

Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail

title: Susan Hail Grave
listingDescription: To overland emigrants the rigors of the trail began with the "Coast of Nebraska," the ridge of sandhills separating the Platte Valley from the open prairie behind it. Thousands of emigrants passed this way during the peak emigration years of the 1850s. Hundreds died of disease, principally of Asiatic cholera. It is believed that a grave near here is of one such victim. Of all those who died, only a few graves are known.
bodyText:
Marker Text:

"To overland emigrants, the rigors of the trail began with the "Coast of Nebraska," the ridge of sandhills separating the Platte Valley from the open prairie behind it. Thousands of emigrants passed this way during the peak emigration years of the 1850s. Hundreds died of disease, principally of Asiatic cholera. It is believed that a grave near here is of one such victim. Of all those who died, only a few graves are known. On August 3, 1859, a surveyor noted the grave and its marker: Memory of Susan O. Hail of Lafayette County, Missouri Who died June 2, 1852 Age 34 Yrs. 5 months 12 days. That marker, since destroyed, was of polished workmanship, unlike most trail gravestones. It is said her husband returned to Missouri, had the stone made, and brought it to this spot on the prairie. The people of the area have cared for the grave, and the land was purchased in 1958 and presented to Adams County by the Federated Women's Club of Kenesaw and the Adams County Historical Society."

Site Information

Location (7000-7938 N Denman Ave, Kenesaw, Adams County, Nebraska)

Oregon National Historic Trail

title: Tamástslikt Cultural Institute
listingDescription: "Tamástslikt " (pronounced "tuh-MUST-slickt") is from the Walla Walla Indian language, meaning "interpreting our own story." This museum and research facility is the only American Indian owned and operated interpretive center on the Oregon Trail. Its permanent exhibits explore the past, present, and future of the Cayuse, Umatilla, and Walla Walla people (the Confederated Tribes.)

images.altText: A large, brown, wood sign stands in a grass lawn in front of a large stone, wood, and metal building
images.caption: Tamastslikt Cultural Institute Entrance

bodyText:
"Tamástslikt" (pronounced "tuh-MUST-slickt") is from the Walla Walla Indian language, meaning "interpreting our own story." This museum and research facility is the only American Indian owned and operated interpretive center on the Oregon Trail. Its permanent exhibits explore the past, present, and future of the Cayuse, Umatilla, and Walla Walla people (the Confederated Tribes) and tell the Oregon Trail story from their perspective. 

Site Information

Location (Highway 331 west of Pendleton, Oregon)

Temporary exhibits explore a variety of other subjects, and during summer months, the institute offers a living culture village where visitors can learn how to pitch a teepee or use an atlatl (spear-thrower). Maps and audio guides for the Cayuse, Umatilla, and Walla Walla Homeland Heritage Corridor are available here, too.

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
The building consists of two long, low wings extending out from the central lobby, angled slightly towards us. Above a dark stone foundation, the walls are sheathed with horizontal wood siding stained a warm reddish brown. The metal covered roofs are curved up and over the wings. The roof over the lobby area slants down towards us with a dormer window perched near the top in the center. At right of the entrance is a wooden sign that reads, "Tamastslikt Cultural institute." Above the carved letters are three carvings in square blocks - a paw print, a fish and a horse.

Under the covered entrance patio, the center wall is made of stone and curves out towards us, flanked by large window panels. A bench sits in front.

The entrance is at the right end of the curved wall and leads into the large, open lobby. The information desk is directly ahead. In the lobby the floor is made of smooth flagstones. The vaulted ceiling is supported by open wooden truss work, all in a natural wood color. A large teepee stands in the middle of the lobby.

A hallway extends to the right as you enter with a seating area and a large gift shop just down on the right side.

title: The Archway
listingDescription: The Archway is a unique trail-themed building that spans the emigrant trails, now part of Interstate 80. The facility tells this story of 170 years of westward movement with detailed displays, family activities, education programs, and more.

images.altText: A metal sculpture of two people riding a horse is located at the entrance plaza for the Archway Building, a large stone, wood, and metal structure
images.caption: The Archway Building Enttrance

bodyText:
Stretching for 310 feet, The Archway is a unique trail-themed building that spans the Oregon Trail, now part of Interstate 80. Emigrants who used the Oregon Trail settled in numerous places, including throughout Nebraska. This amount grew as land was increasingly claimed in Oregon. Soon, towns formed along the Trail in several locations and they used the Oregon Trail for local transportation.

As time passed in this part of Nebraska, trains replaced wagons and parts of the Oregon Trail became a railroad. Later still, automobiles replaced trains and the Oregon Trail became a road. First, it was the rugged Lincoln Highway and then it was further developed and turned into today's Interstate 80.

The Archway tells this story of 170 years of westward movement with detailed displays, family activities, education programs, and more. Amenities include a gift shop, a theater, and a snack bar. Modest admission is charged. 

Site Information

Location (I-80 Exit 275 near Kearney, Nebraska)

 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail

Pony Express National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
The Archway. 382 words

From the parking lot the arched building can be seen extending over the Interstate highway with squat, square towers at either end. The entrance building extends out in front of the tower, with wings on either side. The building is made of large, horizontal logs with light-colored caulking. Broad stone pillars anchor the corners of the lobby and of the wings. The structure is covered with a green metal roof. On top of each of the towers is a gleaming metal sculpture of a leaping horse with huge, fan-shaped wings.

Between the building and the parking lot is a fort structure containing a maze. Continuing past that is a large sculpture of a bison by Nebraska artist Gary Ginther. Feel free to touch. In front of the entrance is another sculpture, this one surrounded by a chain fence. The sculpture is of two boys on horseback in full gallop, their bodies pinned together by an arrow. A nearby sign tells us that this work was commissioned by Fred A. Bosselman and sculpted by David L. Biehl in 2011. Titled "A Narrow Escape," it depicts the Martin brothers running from an Indian attack. Both boys survived.

In front of the sculpture a circular garden surrounds a flagpole. There are benches along the sidewalk around the garden area. Beyond that, on the other side of the entrance road, is an iron foot bridge over a narrow lake. There are more exhibits and a walking path on the other side.

At the right end of the building is an old sign for the Hammer Motel. A wayside sign along the sidewalk there tells us about the Lincoln Highway, an ambitious project to create a highway from coast to coast in the early 1900s. The Hammer Motel was one of the motels that grew up along the highway.

The building entrance leads into a large two-story lobby paved with flagstones. To the left is a dining area. Directly ahead is an escalator leading up to the exhibits in the arch itself. Costumed docents are stationed there to take tickets and provide information. To the right is a large gift shop where tickets may be purchased. There are benches along the wall on either side of the entrance doors.

title: The Archway- Pioneer Sod House
listingDescription: The Archway also contains a variety of outdoor recreation opportunities. The Great Plains Cultural Learning Trail travels through native prairie vegetation to a replica sod house.

images.altText: Looking at the outside of a small sod home with a roof composed of sod, wood, and living plants
images.caption: Pioneer Sod House at The Archway Site

bodyText:
The Archway also contains a variety of outdoor recreation opportunities. This includes fishing in the fish pond, picnicking in covered pavilions, dry RV camping, and hiking and biking on the 13.2 mile Kearney Hike and Bike trail. Several statues with informational signs are found through The Archway's grounds.

In addition, the Great Plains Cultural Learning Trail travels through native prairie vegetation to a replica sod house. Interpretive waysides along this trail tell the story of the people who lived in the area, from the Plains Indians to homesteaders. 

Site Information

Location (I-80 Exit 275 near Kearney, Nebraska)

 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
The Archway- Pioneer Sod House. 488 words

Here on the far side of the bridge in front of the Archway Monument there is a picnic area directly in front of you. Two steps lead up to the large pavilion covered with a green metal roof. Three rows of picnic tables fill the area.

To your left, a paved trail wanders long the lake. A nearby sign has a map that shows how this trail connects with a network of trails through and around the City of Kearny. There are several wayside signs and exhibits as well as benches along this section near the Archway.

First along the right side of the trail are flat metal sculptures of an adult bison with a calf. Feel free to touch. The wayside sign, titled "Fate of the American Bison," tells of the intense hunting that reduced the number of bison from as many as 60 million to only 541 animals in 1887. Today, living on preserves and ranches, the bison numbers have increased to about 200,000. On the left side of the sidewalk are more bison statues. These are made of open metal mesh.

Farther down the trail on the right is a path that leads to a Pawnee Earth Lodge. A sign on the far side of the bridge tells us that the lodge was built in 2010 by members of the Mandan, Hidatsa and Arikara Nations from North Dakota and the Pawnee Nation of Oklahoma. About the size of a small house, the lodge is a circular mound of earth, now covered with vegetation. Here and there an underlying wood beam can be seen. The entrance tunnel is made of vertical poles topped with a log roof. The entrance is closed with a metal gate.

Past the lodge on the tail is a wayside sign titled "The Never-Ending Line." It describes the conflicts between settlers and Indians did not end until the Sioux, Cheyenne and Pawnee peoples were forced onto reservations in the 1870s.

The last exhibit along this trail section is a reproduction of a one-room sod house. The sign on the other end of the bridge tells us that the 224 blocks for the house were made from nine parts dirt and one part Portland Cement. The roof includes 37 saplings, 8 split Nebraska Red Cedar logs and 10 inches of soil. One sign at the right side of the path leading to the house discusses life in a sod house. On the other side, another sign explains how a sod house was made.

The entrance to the house is closed with a metal gate. Looking through you can see a bed made of logs in the back-left corner, covered with a patchwork quilt. A couple of small woven rugs are on the dirt floor. A wooden chest sits against the back wall along with a wash tub and cooking pots. The inside walls are white-washed.

title: The National Oregon/California Trail Center
listingDescription: The National Oregon/California Trail Center offers visitors a unique and entertaining interpretive indoor adventure; simulating an actual wagon train experience of the 1850s. Re-enacted entirely within our comfortable center, this interpretive experience features historically accurate interpretive areas and live actors. Patrons will go back in time to visit a gun shop, mercantile, ride in a covered wagon and spend time around a wagon train.

images.altText: The outside of the National Oregon/California Trail Center in Montpelier, Idaho
images.title: National Oregon/California Trail Center
images.caption: The National Oregon/California Trail Center in Montpelier, Idaho

bodyText:
The Nation Oregon/California Trail Center offers visitors a unique and entertaining interpretive indoor adventure; simulating an actual wagon train experience of the 1850s. Re-enacted entirely within our comfortable center, this interpretive experience features historically accurate interpretive areas and live actors. Patrons will go back in time to visit a gun shop, mercantile, ride in a covered wagon and spend time around the evening encircled wagon train at the Clover Creek Encampment.  

The National Oregon/California Trail Center and the City of Montpelier, Idaho are located on the historic Oregon/California Trail, mid-way between Jackson/Yellowstone and Salt Lake City. Our hotels, restaurants and location are within the beautiful Bear Lake Valley and offer the tourist traveler a unique vacation stopover.

Step Into the Days of the Oregon Trail by taking our simulated Wagon Trail Adventure. You and your family will become members of a simulated wagon train headed west and be guided by our live cast of pioneers whose dialogue and stories will make the adventure come alive! Sign up at our front desk.

The Center also offers spacious and clean restrooms, the Peg Leg Smith Trading Post gift shop, exhibits , Rails and Trails Museum, the Allinger Community Theatre, an original art exhibit of Oregon Trail paintings by Idaho artist Gary Stone and the beautiful murals of artist-in-residence John Wayne Cook. This will be an experience you will never forget!

Site Information

Location (320 North 4th Street, Montpelier, Idaho 83254)

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

title: The Summit Road
listingDescription: The Scotts Bluff Summit Road is a 1.6 mile drive to the summit of Scotts Bluff. Along the way, drivers gain 435 feet and pass through three tunnel, the only three vehicle tunnels in the state of Nebraska.

images.altText: A car approaches one of the tunnels on the Summit Road.
images.title: A Car on the Summit Road
images.caption: A car approaches one of the three tunnels on the Summit Road.

bodyText:
The Scotts Bluff Summit Road is a 1.6 mile drive from the visitor center to the summit of Scotts Bluff. First opened to the public on September 19, 1937, the road leads through three tunnels and features the oldest concrete road surface in the state of Nebraska. 

Vehicles longer than 25 feet and/or higher than 11 feet 7 inches are prohibited. All trailers are prohibited.


*Summit Road access may be restricted at any time due to unsafe conditions including rock falls and weather related conditions. Feel free to call the park at (308) 436-9700 for updated conditions.
audioDescription: A concrete road leads between two buildings. In the distance the road can be seen curving to the left and climbing up a steep escarpment.

title: Three Island Crossing Overlook
listingDescription: Three Island Crossing Overlook is located on top of the bluff across the river from Three Island State Park (directions available at the park's education center). 30 miles eastward from this spot, the Oregon Trail left the Snake River and traveled across dry plains until near the overlook, where once again the trail descended to the Snake River. Emigrants would then attempt to ford the river, a risky undertaking that not all of them survived.

images.altText: Looking out over a river valley with green grass and fertile fields.
images.title: Three Island Crossing
images.caption: Three Island Crossing State Park, Idaho.

bodyText:
Three Island Crossing Overlook is located on top of the bluff across the river from Three Island State Park (directions available at the park's education center). 30 miles eastward from this spot, the Oregon Trail left the Snake River and traveled across dry plains until near the overlook, where once again the trail descended to the Snake River. Emigrants would then attempt to ford the river, a risky undertaking that not all of them survived.

Emigrant Remarks

"Wednesday [August] 6 This morning we hired an Indian to show us the ford. After we saw him cross we determined to try it ourselves. We accordingly commenced making preparations. We crossed two slews to the second island. Here we put ox yokes under the wagon loads to raise them, and put four yoke of our best oxen to each of the four first wagons that crossed. These four got over safely. We then sent the teams back to fech the other three wagons... Suffice it to say we all got over, our cattle and all safely." Robert Haldane Renshaw, 1851

Site Information

Location (Glenns Ferry, Idaho)

Today, the overlook is managed by the State of Idaho. Numerous trail ruts and swales can be seen on the high mesa surrounding the overlook. Amenities include a small gravel path, interpretive wayside exhibits, and parking. The three islands from which the crossing gets its name are visible from the overlook. Parts of the road to the overlook are unpaved but suitable for most vehicles in dry weather. 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
Three Island Crossing Overlook. 311 words

From the parking area, a short dirt path leads to an overlook at the edge of the bluff where a short stone wall holds two wayside signs. From here, there is a sweeping view of the river below, moving in a wide curve away from us. At the curve's bend, the river expands to flow around three small islands. The one on the left is roughly semi-circular. The middle is long and narrow. The one on the right, closest to the main river channel is also very narrow, but only half as long as the middle one.

On the far side of the river the visitor center at Three Island State Park can be seen, with bluffs in the distance backed by high mountains at the horizon. On this side of the river, the land, covered with sagebrush, slopes steeply down to farmland at the river's edge.

One of the wayside signs tells us about the river crossing here, illustrated with a drawing of wagons moving down the steep bluff, crossing to the largest island from the far side of the bend, then across the nearest end of middle island and finally floating across the main river channel. Text reads, "Upon reaching Three Island Crossing of the Snake River, usually by mid-August, Oregon Trail pioneers had a difficult decision to make. Should they cross the sometimes dangerous Snake River using the islands as giant stepping stones or endure the safer but drier route on the south bank of the river? About half of the pioneers attempted the crossing, with diary accounts of many deaths and great loss of personal belongings. A successful crossing meant a shorter route and better food for livestock. The Three Island Ford was used by the Oregon Trail pioneers until 1869, when Gus Glenn constructed a ferry about two miles upstream."

title: Three Island Crossing State Park
listingDescription: Three Island Crossing was the most important and difficult river crossing in Idaho. Crossing the Snake River was always dangerous, but when the water was low enough to negotiate, everyone who could, forded the river here. This allowed emigrants to take the more favorable northern route to Fort Boise. If they were unable to cross, emigrants were forced to travel along the alternate south route into Oregon.

images.altText: A concrete sidewalk winds through multi-colored plants and rocks to a large grey and white building
images.caption: Three Island Crossing State Park Visitor Center

bodyText:
Three Island Crossing was the most important and difficult river crossing in Idaho. Crossing the Snake River was always dangerous, but when the water was low enough to negotiate, everyone who could, forded the river here. This allowed emigrants to take the more favorable northern route to Fort Boise. If they were unable to cross, emigrants were forced to travel along the alternate south route into Oregon- a dry, sandy, dusty, and hot trail that wore out man and beast. Three Island crossing remained active until 1869 when a ferry was built across the river. The crossing is now part of Three Island Crossing State Park.

Emigrant Remarks

On September 11, 1843, William T. Newby ". . . crossed Snake Rive[r]. First we drove over a part of the river one hundred yards wide on to a island, the[n] over a northern branch 75 yards wide on a second island; then we tide a string of wagons together by a chane in the ring of the lead cattles yoak & made fast to the wagon of all a horse & before & him led. We carried as many a[s] fifteen wagons at one time. . . . The water was ten inches up the waggeo[n] beds in the deepe places."

Site Information

Location (Glenns Ferry, Idaho)

The park contains a history and education center, a campground, cabins, picnic areas, and interpretive trails. When near the education center, look across the river to see trail ruts descending from the bluff to the Snake River fording spot. Modest admission is charged.

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
Three Island Crossing State Park. 310 words

The visitor center is a one-story building that fans out in front of you as you approach from the parking lot. The gray flat roof slopes slightly up towards the rear. The walls are also gray, covered with a horizontal siding. The sidewalk passes through a small plaza with native plantings and boulders on either side and forming a small island in the middle. About halfway along the left side there is a cement square with embedded footprints of various animals and of people, forming a guide to footprints that can be found in the entrance walkway itself. Feel free to touch.

The entrance itself is flanked by two rough stone walls that funnel you towards the double glass doors. Engraved on stones in the wall are names of donors. Overhead a canvas canopy circles a central pole.

To the left of the entrance area is a covered wagon with a stone fire circle in the dirt alongside. Feel free to touch. Looking in this direction you have a view of the river beyond, the land on this side flat and covered with grasses and sagebrush. Steep bluffs rise on the far side, one with a clear road scar sloping down to the farmland edging the river.

Back up the entrance drive, to the right of the visitor center is a covered pavilion with two wagons, protected by a low railing. Interpretive signage there tells us that one is Idaho's Bicentennial Wagon, which joined other state wagons in journey from Fort Laramie, Wyoming, to Valley Forge to celebrate America's Bicentennial. The other one is a conestoga wagon.

Out in the sagebrush to the west of the visitor center and the wagon pavilion you can spot a cement post, marking the path of the wagon trail as it came up from the river crossing.

title: Town of Kansas Bridge (Westport Landing)
listingDescription: Westport Landing is where many eastern emigrants ended the first leg of their journey via riverboat and began preparations for their long overland journey. This steamboat landing was established in 1834 and a village quickly grew up around it with the name of "Kansas." This village later evolved into the City of Kansas, which is now known as Kansas City.

images.altText: Looking down a long, wood pedestrian bridge, with concrete and metal side rides, that is bordered by trees and shrubs in great density
images.caption: The Town of Kansas Bridge

bodyText:
Westport Landing is where many eastern emigrants ended the first leg of their journey via riverboat and began preparations for their long overland journey. This steamboat landing was established in 1834 and a village quickly grew up around it with the name of "Kansas." This village later evolved into the City of Kansas, which is now known as Kansas City. The Town Of Kansas Bridge provides access to the landing site. Note, the bridge does not cross the Missouri River, but rather, it crosses railroads and a floodwall.

Site Information

Location (Terminus of North Main St., Kansas City, Missouri)

Found on the 650 foot long bridge are numerous interpretive waysides that tell the stories of Westport Landing, Kansas, and emigrants. The bridges paved path ties into the 15 mile long Riverfront Heritage Trail, making this a great place to go for a walk or a bike ride.

 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

Santa Fe National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
Town of Kansas Bridge (Westport Landing). 413 words

From the end of the street here, an elevated walkway leads out to overlook the edge of the river. A benched seating area is on your left as you enter the walkway. At the right of the entrance to the walkway is a historical marker with a brief discussion of the early history of the "Town of Kansas," ending with the information that Westport Landing became the trails gateway for westward emigrants on the Oregon Trail.

The flooring of the walkway is made of horizontal wood planking, providing a fairly smooth surface. After an initial section that has cement walls on either side, the walkway is edged with metal grillwork with a large heavy mesh, providing views of the ground below. The metal fencing is about 4 feet high. About half way long the walk, where it passes over railroad tracks, the grillwork continues up over head, forming a metal mesh tunnel. At the entrance to this tunnel is a metal archway with a sign that reads, Town of Kansas Bridge. Open landings on either side of the walkway at this point have wayside signs. The one on the right covers the development of the town from steamboat landing to city from 1838 to 1855. The other one describes development of the waterfront town to a metropolis from 1856 to 1880.

At the edge of the river, the walk opens up into a semi-circular platform, providing views up and down the river. To the left are two river bridges, both with steel superstructures. To the right is a single bridge with white metal truss work.

On the left side of the back of the platform are two more wayside signs. One discusses the effort in 1855 to make the city accessible by cutting streets south through the bluffs along the Missouri River. The other one discusses the Gilliss House Hotel which sat on the riverfront.

On the other side of the platform is a staircase which descends to river level where there is a cement walking trail along the river, leading eastward to the Berkley Riverfront Park. There is also an elevator down to that level. More waysides are along the sidewalk covering topics such as the Hannibal Bridge, the first railroad bridge across the Missouri River; John C. McCoy who was a founder both of Westport and of the town of Kansas; and the three trails, Oregon, California and Santa Fe, which passed here through the Westport Landing.

title: Town of Kansas Bridge- Riverfront Heritage Trail
listingDescription: The Riverfront Heritage Trail is a fully accessible 15 mile bicycle and pedestrian pathway that begins at the riverfront and winds through the oldest and most historic parts of bi-state Kansas City. It links communities, parks, and places and ties into the surrounding midtown and suburban trail system. Interpretive waysides and historical markers along the trail create a journey through the early history.

images.altText: An interpretive wayside sign stands in a grass clearing with the large Missouri River flowing behind it
images.caption: Riverfront Heritage Trail Waysides

bodyText:
The Riverfront Heritage Trail is a fully accessible 15 mile bicycle and pedestrian pathway that begins at the riverfront and winds through the oldest and most historic parts of bi-state Kansas City. It links communities, parks, and places and ties into the surrounding midtown and suburban trail system. Interpretive waysides and historical markers along the trail create a journey through the early history of this region, which includes emigrants traveling on the Oregon, California, and Santa Fe Trails. 

Site Information 

Location (Terminus of North Main St., Kansas City, Missouri)

 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

title: Trailside Center, Kansas City
listingDescription: Located just off of 3-Trails Crossing Memorial Highway in the heart of the historic 3-Trails Corridor, Trailside Center provides resources for trail and civil war aficionados, historians, and the Kansas City community. Few visitors realize that the communities that established in this area in the early 1830s were situated at the western edge of the United States until Kansas Territory was established in 1854.

images.altText: A large modern steel looking building
images.title: Trailside Center
images.caption: Visit the Trailside Center to learn about national historic trails and more.

bodyText:
For nearly a quarter century, residents and pioneers along the western Missouri border ate the dust kicked up by thousands of wagons heading west to Santa Fe, Oregon and California. 

Located just off of 3-Trails Crossing Memorial Highway in the heart of the historic 3-Trails Corridor, Trailside Center provides resources for trail and civil war aficionados, historians, and the Kansas City community. Few visitors realize that the communities that established in this area in the early 1830s were situated at the western edge of the United States until Kansas Territory was established in 1854. 

Site Information

Location (9901 Holmes Rd Kansas City, MO)

The Trailside Center is a visitor information center sponsored through a partnership with the City of Kansas City, Missouri, and the nonprofit Historical Society of New Santa Fe, incorporated in 1977 to preserve and memorialize pioneer history in southwest Kansas City. As with the campsites and hospitable settlers met along their overland journey, the Trailside Center greets visitors today and orients them to historic places in the metropolitan area.

 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Santa Fe National Historic Trail

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail
passportStampLocationDescription: You can earn a Santa Fe National Historic Trail passport stamp and a special Santa Fe Trail 200th Anniversary passport stamp at this site. Ask at the site for more information on Passport Stamps available.

title: Wagon Swales
listingDescription: Swales mark the route of the emigrant trails through Scotts Bluff National Monument.

images.altText: A swale along the emigrant trail route is marked with a wooden post.
images.title: Trail Swales
images.caption: Emigrant trail swales can be seen throughout Scotts Bluff National Monument.

bodyText: As you continue west along the Oregon Trail Pathway, look off to the left of the trail and you will see a shallow ditch. Here the wagon trail curves to the left. Though Scotts Bluff National Monument once had ruts, pairs of parallel depressions left by wagon wheels, they have all eroded as the sandstone and siltstone that make up the ground through this area is soft and easily eroded. Instead of ruts we see these wide depression known as "swales"
audioDescription: A curved section of paved trail. To the east is a view of a pass between two sandstone bluffs. To the west is a relatively flat area occasionally broken by ravines.

tags: lewis and clark national historic trail
bodyText:
In late July of 1804, Meriwether Lewis and William Clark arrived in present-day Council Bluffs. The Western Historic Trails Center, located on the banks fo the Missouri River in Council Bluff, Iowa, details their journey from St. Louis to the Pacific. Known as the Loess Hills region, unique deposits of windswept loess soils left behind by the last Ice Age rise 200 feet above the plains along the river. 

The Western Historic Trails Center is the perfect place to spend an afternoon learning about history, enjoying a musical performance, or even just to stretch your legs. The building itself was designed and built by the National Parks Service as a center of exploration in 1997. Here, visitors have the opportunity to retrace the steps of pioneers who came after Lewis and Clark, walking not only the trail blazed by the two intrepid explorers but also the Oregon Trail, the California Trail, and the Mormon Trail.

Exhibits include sculptures by Timothy Woodman, photos, maps, and quotes pertaining to the trails and America's history of Westward Expansion. Outdoor picnic areas offer a tranquil place to enjoy the sunshine and scenery. Walking and biking paths wind through 400 acres of prairie along the scenic Missouri River, offering a glimpse into what the two explorers and the Corps of Discovery observed more than 200 years ago. 

Admission is free. School and group tours are available, but require advance scheduling by calling the center at (712) 366-4900. Visitors are also encouraged to check the center's website and calendar for upcoming events at https://iowaculture.gov/history/sites/western-historic-trails-center.
audioDescription: A low-lying building of gray stone with glass doors and a ring of windows around its second story sits on a green lawn. The building is framed by three medium sized deciduous trees and a tall, gray brick wall on each side in the front and additional tall trees in the back.
passportStampLocationDescription: California National Historic Trail passport stamp, Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail Passport Stamp

title: Whitman Mission National Historic Site, the Oregon Trail
listingDescription: Whitman Mission National Historic Site was established to preserve and share the story of Marcus and Narcissa Whitman's religious mission to the Cayuse Nation in the early nineteenth century, along with its lasting impacts and continuing relevancy. The Whitman's established their religious mission at Waiilatpu on the Columbia Plateau. During the 1840s, the mission also served as a way-stop on the Oregon Trail.

images.altText: The sun shines between two large branches of a massive tree with a brown and tan, one story building in the background
images.caption: Whitman Mission National Historic Site Visitor Center

bodyText:
Whitman Mission National Historic Site was established to preserve and share the story of Marcus and Narcissa Whitman's religious mission to the Cayuse Nation in the early nineteenth century, along with its lasting impacts and continuing relevancy. The Whitman's established their religious mission at Waiilatpu on the Columbia Plateau in 1836. During the 1840s, the mission also served as a way-stop on the Oregon Trail, providing emigrants with food, medicine, and, if needed, a place to stay during the winter. The Whitmans were killed in an attack on November 29, 1847.

Site Information

Location (328 Whitman Mission Road, Walla Walla, Washington)

The National Park Service now manages the mission site, which includes over a mile of paved paths, interpretive exhibits, the graves of Marcus and Narcissa Whitman, a commemorative obelisk, and a visitor center. None of the original mission buildings remain, but their locations are marked. Ranger programs are presented daily from Memorial Day through Labor Day.

Whitman Mission National Historic Site

Oregon National Historic Trail
audioDescription:
The visitor center is housed in a low, irregularly shaped building with a flat roof, sitting in a grove of mature trees. The smooth walls are painted tan with dark brown trim. The area surrounding the building consists of pasture-like fields with tall grass and backed by woods.

The wide sidewalk leads to the entrance in the middle of the building. Restrooms are located on the outside wall to the right. There is a bench to the immediate right of the doorway, with a drinking fountain on the wall further to the right.

The doors open on the carpeted lobby space with the information desk along the back wall straight ahead, just past a glass case which holds a model of the surrounding area. The back wall is made of large windows giving a view of the fields and trees and the paved path leading to the mission foundations behind the visitor center.
